data.title: College UA Ruhr: Ruhr Region
data.text:
Striving for Excellence in Research

The University Alliance Ruhr provides a conducive framework for cutting-edge research and cross-university, interdisciplinary collaboration: researchers and students alike profit from short distances between the universities’ facilities as well as joint institutions and programmes. The member universities offer a highly diversified infrastructure of faculties and departments, complemented by collaborative research centres and research training groups funded by the German Research Foundation (DFG) as well as research clusters. Two of these clusters were selected for funding as part of the “Excellence Strategy” of the Federal Ministry of Education and Research for 2019 to 2025. The Research Alliance was established to interlink the universities’ particular strengths in research. All universities maintain strong international partnerships and networks, including the European University Alliances AURORA and UNIC.

Social Sciences and Humanities

The importance of the social sciences and humanities in the region lies in the broad spectrum of disciplines and specialisations assembled here, as well as in the number of excellent researchers. This concentration of competence in different fields holds high potential for productive collaboration and innovation.

Research fields and specialisations include (list not exhaustive):

research on migration, diversity, integration, and social movements

literary studies, cultural studies, East Asian studies

research on global cooperation and governance, development, and peace

media studies, film and performance studies, international journalism

philosophy and religious studies

A vivid cultural and artistic scene has been thriving in the Ruhr region for decades, gaining substantially in international attention when the “metropolis Ruhr” became European Capital of Culture in 2010. Dense networks between cultural institutions – such as 21 art museums and 11 theatres – have formed across city borders, enabling joint events and exhibitions. As a result, the cultural landscape is both broad and rich in variety, covering a wide range of sectors and styles.

With the Ruhrtriennale, the region hosts a renowned international festival of the arts attracting tens of thousands of visitors each year. Further cultural attractions are the philharmonic orchestras of Bochum, Dortmund, and Essen, hosting several international guest ensembles each year, as well as the internationally renowned Museum Folkwang with its impressive 19th and 20th century art collection. Not to be overlooked, the Ruhr area also harbours a lively scene of urban culture and performing arts, independent cultural societies and clubs, art cinemas, and diverse venues for music shows and festivals of all styles.

Contrary to common prejudice linked to its industrial past, the Ruhr area has a distinct “green side” that is worth exploring. Both within its cities and in the outskirts, you will find a unique patchwork of urban green spaces and natural areas, ranging from parks and botanical gardens, to rural landscapes with farmland and pastures, to meadows and extensive woodlands. The region accommodates a wide range of outdoor activities, and numerous hiking trails invite visitors to discover the landscape. Adding to the scenic charm, the Ruhr, its reservoir Lake Baldeney in Essen, or Lake Kemnade in Bochum are well suited for water sports and cycling or walking along the banks. The Ruhr area can also be explored easily by bike owing to a network of cycle paths, partly along former railways.

Learn more:

Overview of outdoor activities: www.ruhr-tourismus.de/en/anne-frischen-luft

Cycling in the Ruhr area (website in German): www.radrevier.ruhr

Overview of parks and gardens (European Garden Heritage Network):

www.eghn.org/en/regional-routes/north-rhein-westphalia/ruhrgebiet

Apart from its cultural diversity and green spaces, several other aspects make the Ruhr region attractive as a living environment. Compared to other metropolitan areas in Germany, the average rent level is relatively low, while the infrastructure for all necessities of daily life, such as shopping facilities, restaurants, and medical services, is well developed. Mobility is ensured through widely accessible public transportation and complementing services such as carsharing. Due to the short distances between cities and to bordering regions, there is a remarkably wide range of cultural and leisure activities to choose from.

Not only on account of housing costs, the Ruhr area offers a family-friendly environment. Numerous primary and secondary schools (public and private) are available, including several with a special “Europe” profile as well as a few international schools teaching in English and offering international degrees. Childcare and early childhood education have been expanded significantly in recent years. Activities offered specifically for children and young adults include sports as well as musical and cultural education.
